paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR gene and its variants, particularly focusing on the V30M mutation, its penetrance, and the clinical implications in hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis.

patients.phenotype: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTR) with varying onset and penetrance

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Nine Swedish ATTR V30M patients with histopathological and DNA confirmation of the diagnosis that were undergoing liver transplantation were enrolled in the study.

functional_data.summary: The V30M mutation in TTR leads to misfolding and aggregation of the protein, contributing to amyloid fibril formation.

variants.segregation_data: The V30M variant segregates with disease in families, as it is an autosomal dominant condition.
variants.evidence_level: High, due to multiple studies confirming pathogenicity.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the differences in penetrance between populations, particularly between Swedish and Portuguese carriers of the V30M mutation.
key_quotes: Despite derived from the same V30M mutation, the phenotype of the disease differs both between and within populations.
The Portuguese population has an early onset and high penetrance compared to the Swedish population that, in general, has a late onset and low penetrance.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper provided clear information on the TTR variant.
